  {panel}

It will be good if Confluence.home properties supports Windows UNC notation to specify location. The reason is because if Confluence wiki runs as a service, then it is unable to perform any automatic drive mapping. Drive mapping only occurs when a user performs a login. UNC can be convenience in the following places:
# Specifying the Confluence data directory: \\MYSERVER\Confluence_share\data
# Specifying the backup location: \\MYSERVER\Confluence_share\backups Specifying the attachment location.

All this would be useful because it can be installed on a local server and the data files can then reside on a mounted file system that is NOT local (i.e. CFIS file system).

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-16649].
  {panel}

We are a very large organization, using many live-templates (Scaffolding). We are passing meta-data values to other pages. However, when running a metadata-report, it shows all results with a particular label (or specificy MaxRestults=30). Suppose we have 3000 pages total that we are calling, and we only show 30 in the report, then it will show 30, and nobody will know the other 2970 even exist.

So if you look at the contentbylabel macro, it says "Showing 1-30 out of 3000", so you know the other 3000 exist. 

To take it one step further, it would be spectacular if it were possible to get this message on meta-data report AND get some arrows for pagination, so it keep me on the same screen and using Ajax (or something similar) allow us to click arrows to see the next 30 results. Similar to the jira-issues macro.

Good USE CASE: Teams at a company want to use Scaffolding and Metadata for project or action tracking. At the end of those projects or actions, they ddon't want them to populate in the table anymore (because they are old), but they don't want to delete them either. They all want an archive of everything they do for future reference. Like many company's the users don't have great adoption with utilizing the labels (nor the knowledge of how the macros interact with the labels), so it's not a simple fix of the end users changing the labels. Hence the need for pagination.

I would like an option for making page changes a two step process.
The first step would be to make the changes to the page, as it is now. When you are done with that you click "Next", and you are then taken to another page which shows a diff of the changes you've made, and allows you to enter a comment for the changes made.

I see some benefits to this:
# You can spot any errors you may have made, which can't easily be spotted on the preview tab. Ie. if you get to remove a row from a table when you just meant to edit one field.
# It makes it easier to get an overview of what changes you have made to the page, in order to summarize them in the comment.
# The extra page should have a "Back" link which would allow you to go back and edit the page again, in case you spot any errors in the changes you've made.

This should probably be made as an option, possibly per user, since it otherwise would change the work flow of existing installations.
fields.summary: Make page modifications an (optional) two step process, improves diffs and summary notes

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-16557].
  {panel}

To demonstrate this limitation, please refer to the following steps:

# Create a space
# In the "Home" page, add the following content:
{code}
h1. Heading A
h2. Heading B
h1. Heading C
{code}
# Create a child page "Child" with this content:
{code}
h1. Heading D
h2. Heading E
h1. Heading F
{code}
# Export the space to PDF

In the resultant PDF:

* "Home" is displayed as the prime heading (h1)
* "Heading A" is displayed as h2, "Heading B" is displayed as h3, and so on
* However, "Child" (the child page title) is displayed as h2 (not h1), "Heading D" is displayed as h3 and so on <-- this is the limitation

In other words, you can see that on the first page the headings are increased by one:

||Wiki||PDF||
|Page Title|h1|
| "h1."|h2|
| "h2."|h3|
|...|...|

From the second (child page) on, headings are increased by two:
||Wiki||PDF||
|Page Title| h2|
|"h1."|h3|
|"h2."|h4|
|...|...|


Because of this reason it's not possible to do a senseful page numbering with css counters. If the headings would be shifted on all pages in the same way, this would be no problem.

A suggestion would be that Page Titles always get h1 in the PDF export and the content headings are always only shifted by 1. Additionally (to keep the possibility to define something like a title page with the very first page title), the very first page title could get something like <h1 class="very_first_page_title">.
fields.summary: PDF export to cater for better heading formatting

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-16472].
  {panel}

I've been using Confluence every day for a year now and just now learned that you can select multiple users at the same time when applying page restrictions. Wow...what a time saver! For the past year I have been wasting a lot of time by:

# clicking on "choose users" to open a new window
# searching on the name of the user I want to add
# checking the box next to the user in the search results
# clicking on "Save as
# repeating for every user I want to add

I wonder if other users out there have encountered the same waste of time without realising that they can add multiple users at the same time by typing in a comma-separated list of usernames into the  _Enter user/group name(s)_ box and clicking _Add_.

The problem as I see it is twofold:
# The _Enter user/group name(s)_ doesn't do quicksearch on names like it does in JIRA. This requires me to know the actual Confluence username
# The Restrictions section of the page encourages me to click on the "Choose Users" tab (perhaps because it's prominent in the UI or perhaps because I don't know usernames). The problem with _Choose Users_ is that it doesn't allow you to choose multiple users.

If we added quicksearch to the user _Enter user/group names(s)_ field it would DRASTICALLY improve the experience. 

*How it works in JIRA*
!http://img.skitch.com/20090724-q1ga6ab83hscrbefnm96u2ycjt.png!

*How it works in Confluence*
!http://img.skitch.com/20090724-t4ei7jppqyhmuy66ybp3hi2rgm.png!
fields.summary: Page Restrictions: Add quicksearch to Enter user/group name(s)

Of curse some wiki's require such a big history list, so this feature should be configurable (number/size/on&off) in admin console. The file size sum limit has the advantage that it delivers a high number of versions on small files but a calculatable maximum for system administrators.

If this is not applicable CONF-5520 would be nice at least!

This issue affects all versions of Confluence up to 3.1 milestone 1. 

If a user has a draft for an existing page that is subsequently removed and purged, these are the problems: 

- we still present a resume draft link from the user's drafts page which when followed leads to the "page not found" screen
- we still present a view changes link from the user's drafts page which when pressed opens a light box which informs the user to check their logs for error output. 

We should not display the above two links in this circumstance. 

Further, we should preserve a user's changes to a page in the event of a delete and present a means for them to simply view or recover their changes. Right now, they have no access to it at all which is bad.

Advanced doc import breaks headers in a word document into multiple Confluence pages where each header is used as the page titles.

For example, before importing into Confluence the hierarchical structure of a document looks like this:
!before.png!

The result would look ugly in pagetree macro because the sort mechanism in pagetree macro does not know anything about the original document hierarchy:
!after.png!

We need a way to make the resulting pages come out sorted nicely as to make the best use out of the import.

Perhaps a work around for this is to give each title a unique header and assign a number as to enumerate them and sort them automatically in the pagetree macro. 

For example DocumentName-1, DocumentName-2 for each header and so on.

Sometimes theme builder or global configuration settings get lost, possibly due to cache corruption. The knowledge base article has some tracking:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFKB/Global+Configuration+Settings+are+Lost

One theory is that a lack of synchronization on this method could be responsible for cache corruption:
DefaultPluginManager.remove()

An additional idea from Adaptavist:
Also on instantiation of the bandana manager have it inject a Boolean into 'com.atlassian.confluence.bandana.debugcheck' into the cache when the map is first created, and have the other bandana methods check for this item's existance then log messages when it's not there?

Both the knowledge base article and this bug report are not reproducible nor confirmed diagnosed.

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-16251].
  {panel}

The 'create space button' macro (which is part of the 'Confluence dashboard macros' plugin) is missing parameters from the macro browser UI.

Whilst addressing CONF-8759, I found that two additional parameters 'width' and 'height' were missing from the current documentation here:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Create+Space+Button+Macro

Hence, I've already added this information to the current documentation (i.e. the page link above) and we should now add them to the macro browser UI.

Suggested wording for the macro browser UI is:

* *Pixel Height*
(for {{height}})

* *Pixel Width*
(for {{width}})

No descriptions are necessary.

Any potential ambiguity that these parameters may cause with the {{size}} parameter is covered in the documentation.
fields.summary: The 'create space button' macro is missing parameters from the macro browser UI.
